s0001.literal: The Changes states that Fuxi, Shennong, and the Yellow Emperor created teachings to civilize the people, and they transmitted descriptions of their officials, making Fuxi have Dragon Master as the name for officials, Shennong have Fire Master as fire names, the Yellow Emperor have Cloud Master as cloud names, Shaohao have Bird Master as bird names.
s0001.idiomatic: The Book of Changes records that Fuxi, Shennong, and the Yellow Emperor established teachings to civilize the people, passing down descriptions of their officials. Fuxi used Dragon Master as the name for officials, Shennong used Fire Master as fire names, the Yellow Emperor used Cloud Master as cloud names, and Shaohao used Bird Master as bird names.

s0002.literal: From Zhuanxu onward, they became teachers of the people and were named according to human affairs, having the officials of Chongli, Goumang, Zhurong, Houtu, Rushe, and Xuanming, but these are already ancient.
s0002.idiomatic: From Emperor Zhuanxu onward, rulers became teachers of the people and officials were named according to human affairs, with positions like Chongli, Goumang, Zhurong, Houtu, Rushe, and Xuanming—but these are already from ancient times.

s0003.literal: The Documents record that in the time of Tang and Yu, Xihe and his four sons were commanded to follow the heavenly patterns and teach the people the seasons;
s0003.idiomatic: The Book of Documents records that during the reigns of Yao and Shun, Xihe and his four sons were commanded to follow the heavenly patterns and teach the people about the seasons.

s0004.literal: Consulted the Four Peaks to raise worthy talents, promote those in obscurity;
s0004.idiomatic: They consulted the Four Peaks to promote worthy talents and raise up those who were obscure and unknown.

s0005.literal: The twelve pastors soothed the distant and brought close the near;
s0005.idiomatic: The twelve regional governors pacified distant lands and brought nearby territories under control.

s0006.literal: Yu served as Minister of Works, leveling the waters and soils;
s0006.idiomatic: Yu served as Minister of Works, controlling the floods and organizing the lands.

s0007.idiomatic: Bo Yi served as Minister of Rites, overseeing the three ceremonies.

s0008.idiomatic: Chui served as Minister of Works, benefiting the use of tools.

s0009.literal: 益作朕虞，上下草木鳥獸；
s0009.idiomatic: Yi served as Minister of Agriculture, managing the plants, trees, birds, and beasts above and below.

s0010.idiomatic: Kui oversaw music and educated the noble sons.

s0011.idiomatic: Long served as Minister of the Interior, conveying the emperor's commands.

s0012.literal: 至于夏殷，雖官名不同，其務則一。
s0012.idiomatic: By the Xia and Shang dynasties, although the official names differed, their duties were the same.

s0013.idiomatic: The Zhou system of officials was then complete.

s0014.literal: 司徒、司馬、司空、司士、司寇，典司五敘。
s0014.idiomatic: The Ministers of Education, War, Works, Justice, and Crime oversaw the five relationships.

s0015.literal: 太師、太傅、太保、少師、少傅、少保，師氏、保氏，承訓振學。
s0015.idiomatic: The Grand Preceptor, Grand Tutor, Grand Guardian, Junior Preceptor, Junior Tutor, Junior Guardian, the Masters and Guardians transmitted teachings and encouraged learning.

s0016.literal: 内史、太史、内宰、作冊、御史，掌書王命。
s0016.idiomatic: The Inner Scribe, Grand Scribe, Inner Steward, Royal Secretary, and Imperial Scribe managed the king's written commands.

s0017.idiomatic: The Outer Scribe and Imperial Scribe managed the king's written orders.

s0018.idiomatic: The Junior Scribe and Imperial Scribe managed the state's written orders.

s0019.idiomatic: The senior, middle, and junior officers administered the three relationships.

s0020.idiomatic: The stewards, scribes, assistants, and laborers managed official affairs.

s0021.literal: 秦兼天下，建皇帝之號，立百官之職。
s0021.idiomatic: When Qin unified the empire, it established the title of emperor and set up the positions of the hundred officials.

s0023.literal: 相國、丞相，皆秦官，金印紫綬，掌丞天子，助理萬機。
s0023.idiomatic: The Chancellor and Vice-Chancellor were both Qin offices, with gold seals and purple ribbons. They assisted the emperor and managed all affairs.

s0024.literal: 太尉，秦官，金印紫綬，掌武事。
s0024.idiomatic: The Grand Commandant was a Qin office, with gold seal and purple ribbon, overseeing military affairs.

s0025.literal: 御史大夫，秦官，銀印青綬，掌副丞相。
s0025.idiomatic: The Imperial Secretary was a Qin office, with silver seal and blue ribbon, serving as deputy to the chancellor.

s0026.literal: 宗正，秦官，銀印青綬，掌親屬。
s0026.idiomatic: The Director of the Imperial Clan was a Qin office, with silver seal and blue ribbon, overseeing imperial relatives.

s0027.literal: 治粟內史，秦官，銅印黑綬，掌穀貨。
s0027.idiomatic: The Superintendent of Agriculture was a Qin office, with bronze seal and black ribbon, overseeing grain and commodities.

s0028.literal: 少府，秦官，銅印黑綬，掌山海池澤之稅。
s0028.idiomatic: The Privy Treasurer was a Qin office, with bronze seal and black ribbon, overseeing taxes from mountains, seas, pools, and marshes.

s0029.literal: 衛尉，秦官，金印紫綬，掌宮門衛屯兵。
s0029.idiomatic: The Commander of the Guards was a Qin office, with gold seal and purple ribbon, overseeing palace gates and guard troops.

s0030.literal: 太僕，秦官，銅印黑綬，掌輿馬。
s0030.idiomatic: The Master of Carriages was a Qin office, with bronze seal and black ribbon, overseeing chariots and horses.

s0031.literal: 廷尉，秦官，銅印黑綬，掌刑辟。
s0031.idiomatic: The Superintendent of Trials was a Qin office, with bronze seal and black ribbon, overseeing criminal law.

s0032.literal: 典客，秦官，銅印黑綬，掌諸侯及歸義蠻夷。
s0032.idiomatic: The Superintendent of Guests was a Qin office, with bronze seal and black ribbon, overseeing feudal lords and surrendered barbarians.

s0033.literal: 郎中令，秦官，金印紫綬，掌宮殿掖門戶衛屯兵。
s0033.idiomatic: The Commander of the Gentlemen was a Qin office, with gold seal and purple ribbon, overseeing palace halls, side gates, and guard troops.

s0034.idiomatic: Generals, marquises, and the Nine Ministers were all Qin offices.

s0036.idiomatic: When Han arose, the Chancellor and Vice-Chancellor had green ribbons.

s0037.literal: 呂后時，丞相綠綬，綠綬亦丞相也。
s0037.idiomatic: During Empress Lü's time, the chancellor had a green ribbon; the green ribbon was also for the chancellor.

s0038.literal: 孝惠、高后時，號相國，綠綬。
s0038.idiomatic: During Xiaohui and Empress Gao's time, the title was Chancellor, with green ribbon.

s0039.idiomatic: In the first year of Xiaowen, it reverted to Vice-Chancellor.

s0040.idiomatic: The Grand Commandant had a green ribbon.

s0041.idiomatic: In the third year of Xiaojing, the Minister of War was established.

s0042.idiomatic: The Minister of War had a green ribbon.

s0043.idiomatic: The Imperial Secretary had a blue ribbon.

s0044.idiomatic: The Director of the Imperial Clan had a blue ribbon.

s0045.idiomatic: The Superintendent of Agriculture had a black ribbon.

s0046.idiomatic: The Privy Treasurer had a black ribbon.

s0047.idiomatic: The Commander of the Guards had a blue ribbon.

s0048.idiomatic: The Master of Carriages had a black ribbon.

s0049.idiomatic: The Superintendent of Trials had a black ribbon.

s0050.idiomatic: The Superintendent of Guests had a black ribbon.
